utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everybody. I'm Jesse Watters along with Emily Compagno, Juan Williams, Dana Perino, and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York, and this is "The Five." President Trump blasting Michael Cohen after his former lawyer pleads guilty to lying to Congress and agrees to cooperate with the special counsel. Cohen saying in court today that he misled Congress about the timeline of a potential Trump organization real estate deal in Moscow, Cohen originally telling lawmakers talks ended in January 2016, but he's now claiming they didn't wrap up until June of the same year. Trump slamming his former attorney in the wake of these developments.

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP
utterances.utterance: He's a weak person and not a very smart person. He's got himself a big prison sentence and he's trying to get a much lesser prison sentence by making up a story. Now, here's the thing, even if he was right, it doesn't matter because I was allowed to do whatever I wanted during the campaign. Well, he's lying about a project that everybody knew about. I mean, we were very open with it. We were thinking about building a building. I decided, ultimately, not to do it. There would have been nothing wrong if I did do it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Meanwhile, investigation-happy Democrats, like little Adam Schiff, are not satisfied with Trump providing written answers to Robert Mueller. Sherrod Brown also hinting the Russian investigation is only the beginning of what's coming.

utterances.speaker: REP. ADAM SCHIFF (D), CALIFORNIA
utterances.utterance: There really needs to be a live interview with the president because you need to be able to ask fault questions in real time.

utterances.speaker: SEN. SHERROD BROWN (D), OHIO
utterances.utterance: There will be investigations of the president using his office to enrich his family. There will be investigations on other things.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Trump is warning Democrats against what he's calling presidential harassment. The president saying he's a counter puncher and may declassify devastating Russia probe documents if they don't back down. What's so funny, Juan? You know those documents are devastating.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Devastating. Devastating.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know, this is the thing about Trump, he always -- you know - - that the advertising, the hype, the Christmas season is here. But with Trump it's every day. It's bigger. It's grander. It's going to be the best --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let's talk about the Michael Cohen situation. So, Trump's legal team is saying what he told Robert Mueller about the Russian deal -- it wasn't even a deal, it matches what -- with Cohen's statement in court today. And there's really no discrepancy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So what's the big deal? Robert Mueller never asked him when the deal fell apart or when it ended, so what's the problem?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Listen, he -- Trump was tweeting in the middle of 2016 after the primaries that there was no deal, nothing going on, no relation, no business going on with Russia.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There was no deal.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And what we know now from Cohen's plea deal today, Jesse, is that, in fact, he was not only continuing to do this deal, not only continuing to brief Trump on it, but actually in touch with Vladimir Putin's office in order to try to get the deal done. So Trump was trying to make money while he's running for president, doesn't tell the American people this, which it says suggests that he's about his interests, his making money --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Everybody knows he was running the Trump organization when he was running for president --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. So why didn't he say straight up. Hey, I'm still trying to get a deal to build a Trump Tower in Moscow. No, he didn't do that. He lied about it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, there was no deal. I guess in your opinion, a deal happens before you sign it, but that's not --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, what he said was he had nothing, no contact, no business dealings going on with Russia. That's what he said.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. Emily, if you are now working with people like Michael Cohen, who's lied a few times, and you're working with Manafort who's also lied, and Rick Gates who's also lied, are you now saying that when they're offering this new testimony that it's not believable because, you know, they're facing hard prison time? Because a lot people are saying that's the reason they've changed their stories.

utterances.speaker: EMILY COMPAGNO, GUEST CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: You can absolutely make that argument, right, that the reason that credibility is pierced is because, obviously, here's a career criminal liar. But that's when corroborating evidence comes into play. That's when the prosecution has to step up and do their job and say it doesn't matter whether you believe this person in this moment based on their history, here's why we are proving when they are lying and when they are telling the truth. So, it means that you need to take the step further in prosecution part. I want to point something else out as well. Just going back to Jim Corsi -- Jerome Corsi --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We know him as Jiff.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Yeah. I want to point out though that people continue predicting prosecution's behavior and kind of trying to ascribe a certain set of structure and parameters to what's going to happen next, not only this investigation but the ancillary ones with prosecutions. And you can never predict and you can never ascribe a certain set of rules, and the reason I'm bringing that up is because with Corsi, he gave them everything voluntarily. He literally sat down with them and said this is my password and here's my phone, here's everything I own and let me help you. And then they called him on something where he said --

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: He called them on something where he said, oh, I don't remember. And they then circled back and said here's evidence to the contrary. He then amended his answer formally and then they still threatened these felony charges of being untruthful under oath in this investigation. So the fact that the prosecution can do whatever they want. They can change their mind. They can make decisions that don't make sense to us or that suddenly represent a tangent in their development means that for all of us trying to kind of predict or read the tea leaves, anything is possible at this point.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, these are brass knuckle players. I mean, you saw the Ted Stevens situation. The same guys were involved in that. And the Enron situation --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know, Jesse, I just want to interject -- I know we've been quick about it, but you're suggesting to Emily that, gee, these guys are liars. They lied about things in the past. But we know from Manafort, right, that in fact he is checked by the prosecutor and that's why the prosecutor broke the plea deal and that's why Trump is now floating the idea of a pardon for Manafort.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Did he float it?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think he floated it.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: I don't think he floated it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He said it's not off the table, literary.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK, so --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's not floating --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What is that? What's that? It's putting it out there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Dana, so, you know, he's going overseas, just about to take off, and Mueller drops this thing -- in Helsinki, the same thing happened.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Dana's rule of thumb --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What's that?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- any time the President of the United States, no matter who it is, travels overseas to one of these big meetings, something happens in domestic politics that keeps your attention divided, and it's frustrating because now you're on a time difference, you're trying to do things with all these other leaders, the G20 leaders, and get that done. So -- but they'll be fine. I actually think that President Trump should -- I think he should defer to Rudy Giuliani, say I'm going to be gone for three days. I want you to be the spokesperson on this. You handle it, and I'm going to focus on the business at hand as the President of the United States.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So no tweeting at all?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm not going to tell him not to tweet. But I think that in terms of engaging -- like today, when he took all of those questions today, I don't think that he needs to do that. When he's in Argentina, he did that today he said what he had to say. And now he can go and do the important business that a President of the United States --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But, Dana, he canceled a meeting with Putin.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, he did. I think that's the right thing to do.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, maybe he's not in bed with Putin as everybody suggests. Greg, did today's developments make you more or less interested in the story?

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: I have a series of four points, and I don't know if I should do them all or just pick one. Let's do them all. All right. Number one, to Emily's point, I don't know Cohen at all, but these crimes seem to be created by an investigation of crimes they couldn't find. So when you find out there's not enough there, you start looking for something else. Or maybe it's just a crime of opportunity or a searching for a crime of opportunity, meaning to stop the guy for jaywalking hoping he has pot in his pocket. And I think when you pull somebody like Cohen in, you're kind of hoping maybe he's going to lie. And guess what? To quote Juan, he did lie, but that's because he likes to lie, and a lot of lawyers, and a lot of handlers, and a lot of muscle men, they lie.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm sorry. Except for Emily. Now I'm with Trump on --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Best lawyer.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- working until you become president. I think -- if I were considering running in 2020, and I do TV for a living, I'm not going to turn down a lucrative gig selling caviar in St. Petersburg because, you know, I may lose.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Might lose.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So that's why -- he's saying like I've got a job. And by the way, it didn't work out. It doesn't mean he's lying. Now the timeline -- now here's the nut of this. It's about a timeline difference, about a real estate deal that happened before an election that never actually happened. You would find more meat at PETA headquarters. This is like really hard. So, again, in the absence of bad news about our great country, the media needs this story. Might have use a metaphor?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Please.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: If Donald Trump were like an amusement park, right? There's all of these great rides. You have the low unemployment log ride. You have the property and prosperity carousel. You have the wages waterslide. You have the peace pendulum. But where's the media? They're all at the worst ride there is, it's the Mueller teacups. They're spinning around, they vomit, inducing orgy, ignoring all the great rides that America is enjoying because we're having such a great time. They need Mueller.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. Heads explode on The View after finding out Obama treated migrants the same way President Trump --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I have another point.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think you've said enough. That's ahead.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Amid the continuing crisis with the migrant caravan, some on the left outraged over comparison to how President Trump's predecessor handled similar situations at the border.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Last I've checked President Obama is no longer in office. Trump is in office. And this -- but Obama defense, you know, doesn't work for me. That's not to say using tear gas, I think it's immoral when you're using tear gas against children. But ProPublica just found that the Trump administration has secretly continued to separate kids from their families. The Obama administration, they never did that. You know, the ACLU says that kind of separation is unprecedented. So this whole, but Obama did it, but Obama did it, I don't care what Obama did. I care what Trump is doing right here, right now.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Meanwhile, Homeland Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen shooting down claims that all the migrants are asylum-seekers.

utterances.speaker: KIRSTJEN NIELSEN, HOMELAND SECURITY SECRETARY
utterances.utterance: Ultimately, we only see about 9 percent, 10 percent of Central Americans who make an asylum claim actually be granted asylum by an immigration judge. If you're coming to get a job, that's not a claim for asylum. If you're coming to be with your family, that's not a claim for asylum.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, Jesse, why don't you respond to what you just saw on The View. I think she was making the argument that this is what-about-ism and, of course, we've got a crisis now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You came to the right person about what-about-ism, Juan. I'll get to that in a minute. I do want to say about the separating the children thing, someone was just brought over here with a young person and they found out that it wasn't a relationship at all. He was raping her and trafficking her. And also, the Obama administration was responsible for placing young people in human smuggling rings that brought them up to Ohio and were working like seven days a week, 16 hours a day. And, you know, if Trump had done that, can you imagine the outrage? Talk about what-about- ism. I want to do a little experiment.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Please.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let's reverse the name Trump and Obama with Obama scandals, OK? Let's just see how you react.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let's say there were alt-righters in MAGA hats with Billy clubs outside of a polling station intimidating black voters from voting. And then -- you know, A.G. at the time, Whitaker, let's say, just gives them a slap on the wrist, OK? How would you feel about that? Also, another one, what about if Trump sold Mexican cartels handguns and rifles, and those rifle shot a U.S. border patrol agent and then Whitaker wouldn't give any documents to Congress and was held in contempt. Outrageous. What if Trump bombed the bejesus out of Libya, you know, got the dictator out of there, created a failed state, then their ambassador died and then they blamed it on a filmmaker and arrested him and then lied about it. Imagine if Trump had done some of the things that Obama did, you guys would've been freaking out.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think you're in a fever state, but I do think -- I do think when these things happen --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- you absolutely went bonkers on Obama, am I right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Justifiably.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, OK. I just want to be clear. And so, Emily, the argument here, I think, comes down to this that there were incidents -- incidents in which the Obama administration used tear gas at the border. The question is, whether or not, and this is the argument coming from the left, they use them on children and people seeking asylum as opposed to people who were engaged in assault versus the customs and border patrol agents.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Right. I think that argument starts parsing and it gets beside the point, which is the fact that border skirmishes have decreased from the past administration to now. And that is notwithstanding the fact that drug and cartel involvement has increased in the last eight years by almost 40 percent, and smuggling seizures at the border have increased by a factor of ten. So what I'm trying to say is that the efficiency at the border now and the respect we should have for those who are securing our border physically for us at the southern line right now should be off the charts. And to go and to respond to the comment on The View, to me it belies an ignorance. It's exactly the point. We should care what happened under the prior administration because we should know what the laws are and what the laws aren't, and where the confusion lies, and why a subsequent administration can do things just like a prior one did or didn't. So that we know and can lobby our legislators and stop talking about it on talk shows and actually --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Hey.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: -- have something substantive to say.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, Dana --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm going to yield my time to Emily.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But the question is, Dana, again, the use of tear gas or similar materials against children. I think that's what -- especially those pictures --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Just remember --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- caught the attention of the American people.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Of course, this -- I go back to this. I don't think there's a single border patrol agent that wanted to use tear gas. They don't want to have to be in this position. And remember, teargas is a way to deal with crowds that are getting out of control in a way that doesn't have disproportionate force, right? You use teargas to disperse the crowd. It's not that they want to do it. That's why the Obama team did it. That is why it's happening. And remember, it's not that the border patrol or the Trump administration that brought the children up. One thing that I think is good is that you start hear reports today that some of the people there are realizing that they are not going to get asylum, this is not going to work, and they're deciding to turn back.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And, Greg, you know, we have is a situation there and saying -- you have now reports of squalid conditions for people. Long, long waits, which comes to Dana's point as to why people maybe just leaving. And the question is, are we, in fact -- there's a Trump administration, in fact, creating a situation where people don't even get to apply for a legal asylum.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's a easy question, of course, not. For one thing, they aren't gassing children. That is a -- what they're trying to do is say, under Obama, we only shot these things at adults, but the Trump administration, they're aiming at kids. That is not true. That's fake. OK, here's an uncomfortable truth about all of these. In terms of pepper spray and gas, Trump has actually -- sounds to me, Obama did it 80 times? That Trump uses less of it because Trump's stance on immigration was unambiguous. He was metaphorically the wall. He said don't come here. We're going to repel you. We do not believe that you're refugees. We believe you're cutting in line. Therefore, that gave a message fewer people were coming. And therefore, you didn't need to use these kinds of dispersing effects. So, I think, President Obama may have seem more compassionate, but by being ambiguous about the border and not telling people right away what our stance is encouraged people to come, and then you have to disperse them. But the compassionate way is law and order and telling them, look, this is what's going to happen. If you come here, this is what's going to happen. But if you do it the right way because the best answer is compassion and order. That's what we have. That's why we let in hundreds of thousands of people every year because we're compassionate and we have an orderly process. When you violate the process and you rush and you threw bottles and rocks, they're going to shoot -- spray at you, but they're not going to shoot it at kids. They're trying to get the guys who are throwing the bottles, so that's a lie.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't think it's a lie. In fact, if you look at this despite --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So you're saying our border patrol were aiming at the kids. Let's get that little kid. You're insinuating that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, I'm saying there were kids there. But, anyway, the larger point to my mind --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: On which I'm right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, that's always true. That's always true. But the larger point is that despite this recent thing with the caravan, in fact, border crossings long continued to go down. Are Stormy Daniels and Michael Avenatti headed for a split-up? Details next on The Five.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right, he was once her defender but now her offender. Stormy Daniels' blasting the hairless haggler Michael Avenatti, saying the court room cue ball sued Trump for defamation without her permission and is demanding answers about donations that she received from donors but she never saw. Quote, for months, I've asked Michael Avenatti to give me accounting information about the fund my supporter so generously donated to -- for my safety and legal defense. Come on, guys. He has repeatedly ignored those requests. So, we went to Mr. Avenatti for comment.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Lost a lot of weight there. All right, Emily, you're the lawyer here, so you claim, I haven't seen any evidence of it.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Oh, God.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: How is this guy -- tell me something. How is he not being investigated by the ABA or disbarred? I mean, a lot of the stuff he does is really shady.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: I totally agree. He should be. And here's what viewers need to understand. So, first of all, not only does he come to the table already with the background being investigated for fraud, being accused of fraud, as well as bankruptcy and issues with funds with his client and his prior firm, but also these single -- or these dove tales, the single largest reason that attorneys are disciplined and or disbarred is for mingling funds. It's basically for being messy with finances and in any way doing anything wrong with client's dollars. Every single one has to be accounted for appropriately and in line with the contract. And he claims, well, the scope has changed and, therefore, you know, I'm sending up this new fund. Well, her contract didn't. And the other largest thing is that the ethics rules are clear. They are staunch that any type of material decision is a client's to make solely. It is never the attorneys. So the fact that he filed the suit on her behalf without her -- even input or knowledge is absolutely crazy. Of course, he should be referred for disbarment and sued for fraud and, probably, malpractice too.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait a second, disbarment?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait a second. Guys --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- listen, I think he's got a lot of issues. I don't think there's any question. But the fact is he said all she's paid him is a hundred bucks and the money that come in and all these go-fund me or whatever, things that were set up was used for her security, used to help her deal with the situation. The one point that you made that struck me is that she says that the defamation suit filed against President Trump was not done with her consent, which would seem like crazy to me. You've got to have the client's consent. But how many lawyers are -- have unhappy clients? I don't think there's a shortage of them.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's true. We don't have time because we have a big surprise coming up.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm nervous about that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, you should be. Dana, I don't think any woman who ends up in this guy's orbit comes out any better?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Do you know what this is?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's a war on women.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It is.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's a war on women.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: WOMYN.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's all you've got to say?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I know we've got to go. I don't want to take up too much time. But really -- so she's in a situation, she's saying -- she's asking where's the money? And she, apparently, as from previous reporting we have heard, that she could use it. She needs it. And also, why does she need security? So that he could get on TV.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That -- it's his fault.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right. You know what, she's in financial straits, I hope she doesn't turn to porn.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, because it's not a good life, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: War on women, too.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I don't know anything about that life, Greg. But thanks for coming to me on that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What do you think in general about whatever?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I mean, I think security costs are cheap. I don't know how he's racked up 600 grand on security for this woman. It doesn't make sense to me. When you have multiple go-fund me pages popping up and shutting down - -

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- that's a really big red flag. And I also heard word in one of the reports that he tried to start representing members of the caravan and he was actually booted out because he was so ridiculous in his temperament and in his style that even the people in the caravan and the other lawyers around them are trying to do noble things, and dude, get the heck out of here.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He's victim shopping.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He is.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He presents himself as the rescuing white knight --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- and he ends up screwing the person he's representing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Exactly, right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Metaphorically, that is. All right, controversy erupts over a Christmas classic, the left's ridiculous new problem with Rudolph, ahead. CHEVY CHASE, COMEDIAN/ACTOR: Emma, I fixed it. Everybody come out quick. Look at the lights.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: The left's new problem with Rudolph in just a second, but first, going full Griswold with a Christmas display could cost one homeowner an insane amount of money. Local officials in New Jersey now threatening to fine a family -- get this -- $2,000 per day if they go forward with their massive Christmas spectacle. Neighbors complain that the attraction creates too many crowds, so now the town wants the family to pay for police security costs. OK, you guys. First of all, I absolutely love Clark Griswold. I am that guy. And this weekend, on my steeped roof, I was on it like a spider, and I was trying to get lights along the gutter. I had my husband holding an electrical cord, which I improvised around me a safety harness. And he was -- like, my dog was barking. He was, like, "This isn't -- this is so not safe. This is so not safe!" And I had -- I got halfway around before I had to give in and abort. So literally, my house right now is half Clark Griswold and half lights hanging off the side. I'm like the neighborhood dump today. But I love it. So tell me, one of you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You know what? I think we should use more movie clips in the show. It's a really good way, if, like, you're not funny enough, to get the audience to laugh a little bit more to kind of carry --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I wonder where that came from?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't know, but I highly recommend it. I actually did a story a few years ago where I went down to a town in Florida, and they had a similar thing where everything was lit up and there would just be massive amounts of people coming from all over.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: How surprising that it was in Florida. How was the weather?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It was beautiful.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It was.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It was very -- I got a nice tan when I was down there.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I was always interested why you went -- whenever you did these -- these packages, it was always in a nice beach.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, we knocked out some quizzes during spring break around the same time. But -- yes, but neighbors have legit complaints about their streets getting crowded up. But you know what I say? Who cares? It's Christmas.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: It is Christmas. And their -- the neighbor was the mayor, you guys. So the reason that the mayor is shaking down that poor guy is because he lives 200 feet away. He's probably jealous, and he has to wade through the crowd, like a grinch before he gets home.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You don't know that. Maybe one of his relatives died through an electrocution of Christmas lights. And every day he comes home, and he sees those lights and he thinks of Uncle Steve, who fried in front of him; and he was never the same. You know, you are so cruel, Emily. It's disgusting.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Uncle Steve. God rest his soul.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Uncle Steve, yes.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Pardon me, I am the Christmas elf. OK, Juan, what would you do if that was your neighbor? Would you, like, go outside with hot chocolate, pass it around?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, I would be upset, because the streets would be crowded. Everything would be a mess. But you know what? I like it, because I want to go see it, so I love that stuff. But I must say, if it's in your neighborhood, and I know because I go into neighborhoods where they have big light displays. And I think this is great fun, but I know there's the throng of people all around.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All high.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You can't get through. And I thought it was not fair of you to go after the mayor because he's the neighbor. He's not trying to -- so he's saying, "Hey, look, you can't get safety vehicles through. Nothing can get through." And you know what happens in -- at least in D.C., like the big one, which is at a bishop's house, it ends at a certain hour so that they know that, basically, it's on from you know, nightfall, around 6, until 9, and then that's it. Nobody else. And they really do it.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: It comports with local ordinances.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: God bless that bishop. Dana, Candy Cane Lane, is that you?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Also, earlier this week, there was another story where a family -- I think it was either -- it was either in Utah or Idaho -- I think was Idaho -- where they -- the family was sued, because they had a similar situation. And guess what? They won on First Amendment grounds.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Guess what?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So I think that we should take this war on Christmas to the Supreme Court, to the new conservative court --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. That's right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- and see if we can end this war on Christmas once and for all.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes!

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: I would take that case.

utterances.speaker: OK, another Christmas controversy we are following
utterances.utterance: Rudolph is under attack. The Huffington Post slamming the classic children's movie as, quote, "seriously problematic" for apparently promoting bullying, racism, sexism, bigotry, homophobia and lack of acceptance. Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: This is my favorite Christmas show, and one of the reasons I liked it so much --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because you're hateful.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- is because it taught me about being kind to others. I mean, the lesson of the show is that you have to be inclusive of everyone and that some people go through a tough time, and you need to be nice to them.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Is that why you keep telling me to watch that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what? Rudolph, you know why his nose is red. He was a drunk, OK?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Oh, God.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He had a substance abuse problem problem.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is how idiotic The Huffington Post is. OK? They're saying that it's about bullying. It's actually against bullying. If you used The Huffington Post logic, you could never have a book that talks about good versus evil, because it would contain evil in it. And they also use that phrase [SIC] "problematic," which is the phrase [SIC] you use when you can't come up with a reason to explain what you think. By the way, this -- The Huffington Post is owned by Verizon. So direct your letters to Verizon. They hate Christmas. They hate cute little deers [SIC].

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, you just blew it. The P.R. -- P.R. office tonight.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: But you're right. It's like they're saying about -- about fairy tales, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: That -- that stories about dragons teach us that they can be overcome.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: That that's why they have that place. So you're right. So Juan, what do you think about the war on now Rudolph, too? You think there's --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This is silly. This is, like, ridiculous. I mean, who doesn't love Rudolph, the red-nosed reindeer? I mean, the argument is that it's sort of an intellectual reductive argument about the fact that there's so much bullying going on, so much picking, not only on Rudolph but on his dad for having a son who has a red nose. And the shaming of the little guy. And then he overcomes. I understand the story. I also understand that you don't want to celebrate things like shaming.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But that's --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Like in Cinderella, you don't want to go on about that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's the story.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But no, but that's -- you're right, Greg. But it's in the story, and I think what they're saying is look at this. And the way --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They're insulting everybody who reads.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, I don't think this is about reading. It's about TV and little kids watching --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Little kids know.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- and see somebody is being bullied and exploited.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They love Rudolph. Everybody who watches it is on Rudolph's side --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Everybody wants to be Rudolph.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- except The Huffington Post, because they're trying -- This is clickbait for a pathetic website owned by Verizon.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Jesse, your take?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, I mean, I empathize with Rudolph. I was severely bullied as a child. And you know --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You deserved it, though.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Was it over your hair?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, my good looks, my intelligence. I was really cast aside. I had no friends.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Counterproductive.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So this was one of those things. I really can see the lessons here. And the point is you don't glorify the bulliers [SIC] when you watch this.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Bullies.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The bulliers [SIC] end up being the bad guys.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The bulliers [SIC]. Those are the French bullies.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The bully-ays.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The bully-ays.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oui-oui.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The bully-ays.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The French always lose.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The bulliers [SIC]. I'm surprised you corrected me, and Dana just sat there. Dana, where are you? Are you awake?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I didn't want to bully you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Good.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Good, good.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: All right. Ahead, "The Five" faces off in an epic battle of trivia.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Bulliers [SIC].

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Find out who will be crowned --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Stupid.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: -- The Quiz Show champion.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. As you know, I love trivia. After all, I've been on "Jeopardy," winning going into the commercial break. Then I lost.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Lost.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK, I lost big-time. Well, now, our good friend Tom Shillue is here and ready to test our knowledge on fun facts like he does on his new show on FOX Nation. It's called "The Quiz Show." You can catch it weekdays at 7 p.m. Tom, take it away.

utterances.speaker: TOM SHILLUE, FOX NATION
utterances.utterance: Here's how it works, guys. Jesse is the only guy who has been on "The Quiz Show," but I hope you all come on. I answer questions. I ask questions. You answer them. You have an A, a B, and a C. OK? I will try to be articulate.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I have a question. Why are you wearing what I wear?

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Greg, let me do the questions!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is mine!

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: I am like -- I'm a poor man's Gutfeld. You know it, Greg. That's what you told me when I started working here.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Why do you have abs (ph)?

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Question No. 1.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Poor man's Gutfeld, that's redundant.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Stop the mutiny.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Question No. 1: In 1970, Richard Nixon signed a bill that prevented the television industry from doing what? A, showing full frontal nudity; B, advertising cigarettes; or C, promoting the gaming industry.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: B.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Emily is too young.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: And Emily -- Emily says C. The answer is --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: B.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I am in first place.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Guys, don't gloat. They get tougher. No. 2, what was the first toy to ever be advertised on television? Was it: A, the Slinky; B, Mr. Potato Head; or C, lawn darts?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I love lawn darts.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: OK. Get your answers up. All different answers here. Greg, you're upside down. You know that? The answer is B, Mr. Potato Head.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Yes, a pure guess.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I went with A.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This is the advantage of having age on your side, Tom.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Well, that's right. And I want you to know, the first Mr. Potato head, his name was "Make a Face."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Really? I bet your parents wouldn't like that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Make a Face? I thought -- I thought it was Shillue. It wasn't Shillue?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Why?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because you were always poking things into a man's face.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You didn't have one?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I had one.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: You had one.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: It actually -- the first Mr. Potato Head, you needed to supply your own potato.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Mr. Potato Head?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, you did. Exactly.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Emily, you got that one right. Greg, what, are you trying to hurry me up?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes!

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Because this --

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: We've got to stay on time.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Moving along, here we go. Question No. 3. The Nevada state prison used to have what available to its inmates? Was it: A, courses on dealing blackjack; B, monthly visits from magicians and face painters; or C, a casino? Greg is still upside-down. B's. A lot of B's, a lot of C's. And the answer is C. A casino.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes!

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Yes. This is my jam.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: How do you keep everybody --

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: We're keeping you honest. Because I think our producers are counting the votes, so we'll know who's the winner. That's right. Between 1932 and 19 --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We don't need to know.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: -- fifty-seven -- Greg, this is the great --

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: We need to know our history.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Greg -- Greg, the following facts are what make "The Quiz Show" so special.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It may be your sad life, Tom. But in my life, I like to move on.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: They had a casino in the Nevada State Prison. That's what I was going to tell you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK, OK. We get it, we get it. Here we go.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: No. 3 -- No. 4. Which fast food mogul once shot a rival in the shoulder while fighting over advertising space? Was it: A, Dave Thomas, of Wendy's, as you know; B, Ray Kroc --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, that's tough.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: -- of McDonalds? Or C, Colonel Harlan Sanders from, yes, KFC? Your answers, please, ladies and gentlemen. All cards are up. And the answer is C.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: The Colonel with a gun! He's strapped. Mad. Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know, this is a family show. Don't you go -- OK.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What did she do?

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Dana and Emily are --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know. I'm very close to swearing.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Dana and Emily are in the lead --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Come on.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: -- with four points each.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Girl power.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Women are achieving everywhere.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Juan has three?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Me, too.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: So you two are behind. You've got to -- you've got to catch up.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let's start back the war on women, Greg.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: You don't have to let them go on? Whose side are you on? Be objective.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Colonel Sanders --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We don't want to know about the facts!

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: He shot a man in self-defense. His own business associate. And the man died. He died.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, wow.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait a second. Wait a second.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's not a good follow-up fact. That's a sad follow-up fact.
